title: This Week’s Weird and Wonderful: January 31, 2025
description: It's been another big week, with the last seven days serving up another batch of the utmost in oddities and wonders—cars, trucks, race cars, and a heaping side of Cold War "corncob."
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Learn more about This Week’s Weird and Wonderful: January 31, 2025 on Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online.
text: It’s been another big week, with the last seven days serving up another batch of the utmost in oddities and wonders—cars, trucks, race cars, and a heaping side of Cold War “corncob.” It’s always tough to limit ourselves to just 10. There’s certainly much more to be seen on the live auctions page, but here are our picks for this week’s Weird and Wonderful! 1. 1956 Allard Palm Beach Mk II Roadster 5-Speed Thus far this Allard Palm Beach roadster seems to have slipped under viewers’ radar, but it’s certainly a special car. Documents in the gallery tell the story—it’s the first of just six Palm Beach Mk. II roadsters, and was restored from 2012-2014 by Lloyd and Alan Allard, Sydney Allard’s grandsons. 545 EXR is also said to be the only one of its kind fitted with the Ford Zephyr six—all others received a 3.4-liter Jaguar engine. @Guido36 hit the nail on the head when he said it looks like “the love child of an AC Ace and and Austin Healey 100.” 2. Pratt & Whitney R-4360 Wasp Major We dare anyone to make this engine into a coffee table. Weighing in at around 3,700 lb., this Ford-built Pratt & Whitney Wasp Major “corncob” radial measures over eight feet tall on its stand (itself reportedly cribbed from a Douglass C-124 Globemaster II cargo plane). The specs on the Wasp Major are just insane to those of us who think of seven-liter V8s as big. With 28 cylinders (double the count of the famous Twin Wasp) displacing 4,360 cubic inches, it was the largest piston engine ever put into production, and we shudder just thinking about doing a tuneup on an engine with 56 spark plugs and 56 valves. There’s just one day left on this auction, and the sale will benefit the Air Combat Museum in Springfield, Illinois, which has been home to a very interesting collection of airworthy warbirds and trainers (including the only flying Fairey Firefly), as well as static display planes and in-progress restorations. 3. 1958 Porsche 356A 1600 Speedster Race Car This old war horse is a perfect example of what SCCA racing looked like in the 1960s and ’70s. Both Bruce Baker and Ed Parlett raced the car, and its dash is adorned with plaques attesting to its successful participation in club races and rallies up and down the East Coast. Period photographs give us a lovely portrait of the grassroots racing scene, with #45 parked in said grass surrounded by Parlett, his wife, and friends—not a hospitality tent or transporter anywhere to be seen. This article from Sports Car Digest adds more color to the car’s history, including this gem of a photo. Ed Parlett, you’re our new hero. 4. 327-Powered Ford Pickup Hot Rod Hot rod aesthetics are wholly subjective, but it’s hard to argue with the details on this eight-year build by Chris Clark of Ace Fabrication. Just about every trick in the book has been applied to the ’36 Ford pickup cab, which has been chopped, channeled, sectioned, and mounted on a custom frame. Mercifully, the door hinges and handles were left intact. We are particularly enamored with the naked Tremec T56 in the cockpit, the quad-carb Holley/Weiand setup, and the polished Tru-Ram exhaust manifolds, but honestly, the entire gallery from @Trust-in-the-Machine is worth your time. 5. 1953 MG TD Inskip 4-Passenger Roadster New York-based MG distributor JS Inskip provided this answer to the surely oft-asked question “how can I fit more people in my MG TD?” He was able to squeeze in the extra seat by adding 10″ to the frame, doors, running boards, and soft top, and we have to say that the proportions of the stretched car work, especially with the top closed. Coachbuilt MGs are always unusual, even more when the revisions alter the car so thoroughly. This is the second car from @hymanltd in this week’s list, so they deserve a round of applause for keeping it weird and wonderful! 6. 1935 Georges Irat MDS Cabriolet Raise your hand if you hadn’t heard of Georges Irat before this auction—we won’t judge. This 1935 roadster from the boutique manufacturer in France is packed full of the kinds of oddities we associate with vehicles built in that country. The lovely combination gauge, Tracta-type constant-velocity joints, and gorgeous little lunchbox of an engine are perfect examples. The car’s front-wheel-drive layout was accomplished by turning the drivetrain backwards and attaching a rod to the otherwise conventionally-placed three-speed shifter. It feels like a solution proposed at 4:45 on a Friday, but seems to work just fine in the driving video! 7. 1986 Nissan Stanza XE 4WD Wagon 5-Speed This is one of those cars that makes us realize we didn’t know how good we had it with Japanese vehicles in the 1980s. The AWD Stanza wagon, like the contemporary 4WD Tercel, was ahead of its time. An economical foul-weather wagon with sliding doors, a five-speed, and Giugiaro-meets-Duplo styling seems like the perfect daily driver, and it’s not the kind of thing manufacturers are going to offer us again anytime soon. 8. Ex–Davey Allison, Taurus-Bodied Ford Thunderbird NASCAR Racer Consider the basics just for a second—a pushrod V8, a stick shift, and a live rear axle in a chassis that’s engineered to cocoon you from the dangers of a 100-plus mph crash—and you quickly come to realize that NASCAR race cars are national treasure levels of a find for the money. This particular example is a Ford Thunderbird that was campaigned by Robert Yates Racing with Davey Allison at the helm during the 1992 NASCAR Winston Cup Series season. And no, your eyes aren’t deceiving you—this example was rebodied sometime during the ’90s to honor Dale Jarrett’s 1999 title win. The Motorsports Hall of Fame of America has had their hands on the racer since 2001, and the engine is said to turn over by hand. The auction ends in five days, and the proceeds will go to the MHFA Foundation in Daytona Beach, Florida. 9. Ford Model A Replica Woodie Panel Truck w/Travel Trailer Splinter Auto Works of Plymouth, Indiana, wasn’t having it with the wood-look appliqués of the 1980s. So the firm took matters into its own hands, recreating a range of ’30s, ’40s, and ’50s-style station wagons and pickups with woodie bodies and fiberglass components. Peep the auction URL, and you’ll start getting an idea of how odd this one is; it’s powered by an inline-four from a 1986 Chevy Chevette and rides on a custom-fabricated tube chassis. The matching teardrop trailer shows admirable woodwork and craftsmanship. The whole package is No Reserve, which means this woodie will definitely be going to a new home in just five days along with everything necessary to take it on your next camping trip (or at least as far as the sub-2.0L Chevette mill is willing to take you). 10. 1942 Indian Four Four-cylinder Indian bikes date back to the late 1920s, just after the firm acquired the Ace Motor Corporation in 1927. Wartime models were especially popular, and this 1942 Model 442 represents the last year of the Indian Four lineup. The current owner is said to have acquired the bike from its original owner.  The listing’s period photographs and start-up videos will give you an idea of what it means to own a bike like this. The auction went live yesterday, and given that only 700 of these were reportedly made in 1942, it’s poised to garner a lot of attention. Honorable Mentions 1990 Nissan Homy Hearse 4×4 5-Speed We’ll leave the “homey” and “wouldn’t want to be caught dead” jokes up to the ever reliable BaT Community.  EV-Converted 1949 Ford F-1 Pickup EV conversions of classic cars and trucks are a polarizing topic, but either way we appreciate the new life that the seller and builder @northev brought back into this old farm truck.  2023 BAC Mono R In the simplest sense, the BAC Mono R is more powerful and lighter than the non-R version. This example holds a California BAR sticker—which itself is worthy to note—and has been enjoyed over just 700 miles. This is the first R spec Mono on BaT, and we can only imagine how it drives. But no need to worry: seller @Wob says videos are to come.  Again, this list is by no means comprehensive; there are many more weird and wonderful vehicles on our pages at any moment. These are just some that we found noteworthy, but we’d love to hear what caught your eye! Let us know in the comments.
html:
It’s been another big week, with the last seven days serving up another batch of the utmost in oddities and wonders—cars, trucks, race cars, and a heaping side of Cold War “corncob.”

It’s always tough to limit ourselves to just 10. There’s certainly much more to be seen on the live auctions page, but here are our picks for this week’s Weird and Wonderful!

1. 1956 Allard Palm Beach Mk II Roadster 5-Speed

Thus far this Allard Palm Beach roadster seems to have slipped under viewers’ radar, but it’s certainly a special car. Documents in the gallery tell the story—it’s the first of just six Palm Beach Mk. II roadsters, and was restored from 2012-2014 by Lloyd and Alan Allard, Sydney Allard’s grandsons. 545 EXR is also said to be the only one of its kind fitted with the Ford Zephyr six—all others received a 3.4-liter Jaguar engine. @Guido36 hit the nail on the head when he said it looks like “the love child of an AC Ace and and Austin Healey 100.”

2. Pratt & Whitney R-4360 Wasp Major

We dare anyone to make this engine into a coffee table. Weighing in at around 3,700 lb., this Ford-built Pratt & Whitney Wasp Major “corncob” radial measures over eight feet tall on its stand (itself reportedly cribbed from a Douglass C-124 Globemaster II cargo plane). The specs on the Wasp Major are just insane to those of us who think of seven-liter V8s as big. With 28 cylinders (double the count of the famous Twin Wasp) displacing 4,360 cubic inches, it was the largest piston engine ever put into production, and we shudder just thinking about doing a tuneup on an engine with 56 spark plugs and 56 valves. There’s just one day left on this auction, and the sale will benefit the Air Combat Museum in Springfield, Illinois, which has been home to a very interesting collection of airworthy warbirds and trainers (including the only flying Fairey Firefly), as well as static display planes and in-progress restorations.

3. 1958 Porsche 356A 1600 Speedster Race Car

This old war horse is a perfect example of what SCCA racing looked like in the 1960s and ’70s. Both Bruce Baker and Ed Parlett raced the car, and its dash is adorned with plaques attesting to its successful participation in club races and rallies up and down the East Coast. Period photographs give us a lovely portrait of the grassroots racing scene, with #45 parked in said grass surrounded by Parlett, his wife, and friends—not a hospitality tent or transporter anywhere to be seen.

This article from Sports Car Digest adds more color to the car’s history, including this gem of a photo. Ed Parlett, you’re our new hero.

4. 327-Powered Ford Pickup Hot Rod

Hot rod aesthetics are wholly subjective, but it’s hard to argue with the details on this eight-year build by Chris Clark of Ace Fabrication. Just about every trick in the book has been applied to the ’36 Ford pickup cab, which has been chopped, channeled, sectioned, and mounted on a custom frame. Mercifully, the door hinges and handles were left intact. We are particularly enamored with the naked Tremec T56 in the cockpit, the quad-carb Holley/Weiand setup, and the polished Tru-Ram exhaust manifolds, but honestly, the entire gallery from @Trust-in-the-Machine is worth your time.

5. 1953 MG TD Inskip 4-Passenger Roadster

New York-based MG distributor JS Inskip provided this answer to the surely oft-asked question “how can I fit more people in my MG TD?” He was able to squeeze in the extra seat by adding 10″ to the frame, doors, running boards, and soft top, and we have to say that the proportions of the stretched car work, especially with the top closed. Coachbuilt MGs are always unusual, even more when the revisions alter the car so thoroughly. This is the second car from @hymanltd in this week’s list, so they deserve a round of applause for keeping it weird and wonderful!

6. 1935 Georges Irat MDS Cabriolet

Raise your hand if you hadn’t heard of Georges Irat before this auction—we won’t judge. This 1935 roadster from the boutique manufacturer in France is packed full of the kinds of oddities we associate with vehicles built in that country. The lovely combination gauge, Tracta-type constant-velocity joints, and gorgeous little lunchbox of an engine are perfect examples. The car’s front-wheel-drive layout was accomplished by turning the drivetrain backwards and attaching a rod to the otherwise conventionally-placed three-speed shifter. It feels like a solution proposed at 4:45 on a Friday, but seems to work just fine in the driving video!

7. 1986 Nissan Stanza XE 4WD Wagon 5-Speed

This is one of those cars that makes us realize we didn’t know how good we had it with Japanese vehicles in the 1980s. The AWD Stanza wagon, like the contemporary 4WD Tercel, was ahead of its time. An economical foul-weather wagon with sliding doors, a five-speed, and Giugiaro-meets-Duplo styling seems like the perfect daily driver, and it’s not the kind of thing manufacturers are going to offer us again anytime soon.

8. Ex–Davey Allison, Taurus-Bodied Ford Thunderbird NASCAR Racer

Consider the basics just for a second—a pushrod V8, a stick shift, and a live rear axle in a chassis that’s engineered to cocoon you from the dangers of a 100-plus mph crash—and you quickly come to realize that NASCAR race cars are national treasure levels of a find for the money. This particular example is a Ford Thunderbird that was campaigned by Robert Yates Racing with Davey Allison at the helm during the 1992 NASCAR Winston Cup Series season. And no, your eyes aren’t deceiving you—this example was rebodied sometime during the ’90s to honor Dale Jarrett’s 1999 title win.

The Motorsports Hall of Fame of America has had their hands on the racer since 2001, and the engine is said to turn over by hand. The auction ends in five days, and the proceeds will go to the MHFA Foundation in Daytona Beach, Florida.

9. Ford Model A Replica Woodie Panel Truck w/Travel Trailer

Splinter Auto Works of Plymouth, Indiana, wasn’t having it with the wood-look appliqués of the 1980s. So the firm took matters into its own hands, recreating a range of ’30s, ’40s, and ’50s-style station wagons and pickups with woodie bodies and fiberglass components. Peep the auction URL, and you’ll start getting an idea of how odd this one is; it’s powered by an inline-four from a 1986 Chevy Chevette and rides on a custom-fabricated tube chassis.

The matching teardrop trailer shows admirable woodwork and craftsmanship. The whole package is No Reserve, which means this woodie will definitely be going to a new home in just five days along with everything necessary to take it on your next camping trip (or at least as far as the sub-2.0L Chevette mill is willing to take you).

10. 1942 Indian Four

Four-cylinder Indian bikes date back to the late 1920s, just after the firm acquired the Ace Motor Corporation in 1927. Wartime models were especially popular, and this 1942 Model 442 represents the last year of the Indian Four lineup. The current owner is said to have acquired the bike from its original owner. 

The listing’s period photographs and start-up videos will give you an idea of what it means to own a bike like this. The auction went live yesterday, and given that only 700 of these were reportedly made in 1942, it’s poised to garner a lot of attention.

Honorable Mentions

1990 Nissan Homy Hearse 4×4 5-Speed

We’ll leave the “homey” and “wouldn’t want to be caught dead” jokes up to the ever reliable BaT Community. 

EV-Converted 1949 Ford F-1 Pickup

EV conversions of classic cars and trucks are a polarizing topic, but either way we appreciate the new life that the seller and builder @northev brought back into this old farm truck. 

2023 BAC Mono R

In the simplest sense, the BAC Mono R is more powerful and lighter than the non-R version. This example holds a California BAR sticker—which itself is worthy to note—and has been enjoyed over just 700 miles. This is the first R spec Mono on BaT, and we can only imagine how it drives. But no need to worry: seller @Wob says videos are to come. 

Again, this list is by no means comprehensive; there are many more weird and wonderful vehicles on our pages at any moment. These are just some that we found noteworthy, but we’d love to hear what caught your eye! Let us know in the comments.
